DOC.HEAD: US Confirms Israel Buying Iranian Oil
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said on Tuesday that Israel made a major oil deal with Iran as part of a reported effort to win the release of three Israeli soldiers being held in Lebanon. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Israel informed the United States of the oil deal a month ago. She declined to say whether the United States approved of the deal. ``Foreign countries do not seek U.S. approval for oil purchases from a third country,'' she added. The United States has no diplomatic relations with Iran and is worried about the possibility of Iranian-backed terrorist incidents against American targets in Europe or Africa during the holiday season. Iran is one of six countries which, according to the State Department, supports international terrorism. NBC News disclosed the oil transaction Monday night, saying that Israel paid Iran $36 million and that one purpose was to encourage Iran to use its influence to help free three Israeli soldiers being held in Lebanon. The United States is backing the deal in hopes that it could lead to the release of American hostages held in Lebanon, NBC said. Ms. Tutwiler said the United States does not make deals for the release of U.S. hostages, but she refused to offer an opinion as to whether there is any objection to Israel carrying out negotiations on behalf of the hostages. In addition to winning the radical Moslem country's help in seeking the release of Israelis, the oil purchases and a potential spare parts deal are intended to bolster Iran's position against a common enemy, Iraq, NBC said. Iran's Islamic fundamentalist leaders are generally hostile to Israel but the country's struggling economy is sorely in need of foreign currency. Spokesmen for Israel's Energy, Foreign and Defense ministries on Tuesday refused to comment on the report. The Defense Ministry also refused to allow reporters to talk to Uri Lubrani, mentioned in the NBC report as the man who dealt with the Iranians in Switzerland. Lubrani is responsible for Israel's Lebanon policy and served as ambassador to Iran before the revolution that swept Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to power. Joseph Alpher of the Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies, executive editor of the center's annual ``Middle East Military Balance'', said Israel had other considerations that could justify ties with Iran, apart from seeking the release of its prisoners. ``Iraq is getting stronger every day by acquiring chemical and non-conventional arms that threaten us,'' Alpher said on Israel Television. ``There is a reason to see to it that Iran can continue confronting and diversing the Iraqi forces.'' ``Beyond that, Iran has oil, Iran has Jews and all these are good reasons for renewal of connections with Iran, without any relation to the governing regime,'' he said.
